title: Lidl and Morrisons to install rapid chargers at around 400 stores by 2022
text:
A Lidl extra range: The supermarket has promised to install electric car rapid charge points at 300 UK stores by 2022

Supermarkets are continuing to ramp up the availability of rapid electric car chargers at their stores in a bid to attract customers.

Lidl has confirmed it will have rapid chargers installed at around 300 UK stores by 2022.

This follows an earlier statement by Morrisons that 100 of these quick-charging vehicle points will be available in supermarket car parks by the end of the year.

Lidl says the introduction of charging points at its stores - both existing locations and future openings in the next three years - will cost around £25million in total.

These rapid chargers are among the most powerful in the UK at the moment and offer the shortest battery boosting times.

Provided by Pod Point, the chargers can replenish the batteries of the latest electric cars from zero to 80 per cent charge in around 50 minutes.

They can be accessed using Pod Point's app and bays will be clearly marked as being reserved for electric vehicles only.

Shoppers will be able to find which stores have installations using the Lidl app or Zap-Map, which is a live locator for all electric-car charge points across the country - of which there are now more than petrol stations, it was revealed earlier this year.

Lidl bosses said the supermarket's commitment supports the Government's plans to deliver a significant increase in quality infrastructure to support ultra-low emission vehicles around the country.

It will be free to access the Point Point chargers, though there will be a fee of 23p per kilowatt hour the vehicle is charging

Ingo Fischer, chief development officer for Lidl, commented: 'Not only will our customers be able to charge their electric cars in 50 mins – less time than it takes to do a big shop – they will be able to do it for the best price on the market.

'It is our hope that, through this significant investment, we will enable easier access to charging points, ultimately helping more households switch to electric vehicles.'

Pod Point's own website says current rapid chargers at Lidl are free to use.

However, Lidl confirmed to This is Money that they will costs 23p per kilowatt (kW) hour.

Pod Point's Tesco units cost about £6.25 for 30 minutes of charging (about 100 miles of range), according to the charge-point provider.

Morrisons says it has already added 50 GeniePoint rapid chargers at UK stores this year, and will have another 50 across the country by the start of 2020.

Morrisons has also promised to install 100 rapid chargers at stores across the UK by the end of the year

These chargers will be located around the perimeter of the car parks to ensure they are available to those who need them and not obstructed by other customers.

Andrew Ball, fuel and services manager of Morrisons, said: 'Customers are beginning to take part in the biggest revolution in car design since the internal combustion engine was first developed.

'We need to follow them and give them the opportunity to charge while they shop.'

Customers will need to register to use the chargers via GeniePoint's app.

There is no monthly fee and drivers only pay for the electricity they use which costs 30p per kW hour.

According to a Zap-Map study in 2017, there were around 600 chargers at almost 300 supermarket locations two years ago.

Asda, Sainsbury's and Waitrose were offering the most availability, according to the report.
description: Supermarkets are continuing to ramp up the availability of rapid electric car chargers at their stores. Lidl will have 300 by 2022, while Morrisons promises 100 by the end of the year.
